doom.driver: Urgent research needed to tackle AI threats, says Google AI boss. But the head of the US delegation at the AI Impact Summit in Delhi says: "We totally reject global governance of AI."
doom.summary: Google's AI chief waves the danger flag at a global summit while the US simultaneously torches the idea of anyone doing anything about it internationally — a masterclass in identifying a problem and then spiking the solution. Meanwhile, Ukraine's patience with the American peace process is evaporating, RSF forces in Sudan are being credibly accused of genocide, and Iran tensions hum along at their now-customary low boil. Nothing exploded today, but the systems designed to prevent explosions keep getting dismantled.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: A Hacker News piece on 17k tokens/second inference speeds signals the capability curve isn't waiting for governance to catch up.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: The US flatly rejecting global AI governance at an international safety summit is exactly the kind of institutional gap that keeps alignment researchers awake at night.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Ukraine-US relations fraying, Sudan genocide findings, Iran nuclear drumbeat continuing — no single escalation but the background radiation of instability remains high.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: Google flagging urgent AI threat research needs while governance frameworks get actively rejected creates a concerning asymmetry between capability and safety.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: A man arrested by police in a lion costume and an anonymous gold bar donation to fix water pipes suggest the timeline is still producing wholesome absurdities alongside the grim stuff.

dawn.driver: Fresh understanding of the causes of migraine reveals new drug targets. New insights into the causes of migraine is prompting a fresh look at a drug target that was sidelined 25 years ago
dawn.blurb: DECADES-OLD PAIN GETS A SECOND CHANCE
dawn.summary: For the hundreds of millions who suffer debilitating migraines, today's news from New Scientist is genuinely meaningful — science revisiting a discarded drug target with fresh eyes is exactly how medicine quietly changes lives at scale. Against a backdrop of geopolitical strain and difficult headlines, this is a reminder that researchers keep showing up, keep asking better questions, and keep finding paths forward. A drug shelved 25 years ago may yet become someone's relief — that's the long, patient arc of human progress doing its work.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Migraine research reopening a previously abandoned drug target demonstrates science's self-correcting, iterative power to revisit old failures with new understanding.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: Alysa Liu winning Olympic gold skating with pure joy — ending a 24-year American drought — is a vivid reminder that delight itself can be a competitive advantage.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: An anonymous Osaka donor gifting gold bars specifically to repair public water infrastructure shows quiet, selfless civic generosity still exists in the world.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: Americans shifting toward rural communities and outdoor lifestyles signals a cultural reorientation toward nature, even if the headline drivers are economic.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Thai police using a ceremonial lion dance costume to make an arrest is absurd and delightful — proof that human creativity and humor persist even in law enforcement.
